# Question

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Here's one possible implementation of the `clean_column` function in Julia:
```julia-repl
function clean_column(col::String)
    col = lowercase(strip(col)) # Lowercase and strip whitespace from both ends.
    col = replace(col, " - " => "_")  # Replace spaces with underscores.
    col = replace(col, "-" => "")   # Remove remaining hyphens.
    return col  # Return the cleaned column name.
end
```
This function takes a string (representing the column name) as input and returns the cleaned version of it. It first converts the string to lowercase using `lowercase()`, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace using `strip()`. Then, it replaces any spaces with underscores using `replace()` and removes any remaining hyphens from the string. Finally, it returns the cleaned column name as a string.
